utterances: I think right now, if you look, you know, there's probably 5,000 to 6,000 people in that region that actually live in that region.
And, you know, some people live outside and have farms, and go into the farms.
But 5,000 to 6,000 were probably driven out with the, before the fighting and during the fighting.

Right now, you may have about 2,000 that are in there right now, living in their homes and maybe one to 2,000 more that are coming in, in the day, working on their farms, and then going back at night to a safe haven.

You know, most of the people really won't come back until they see that the ISAF NATO forces have made a commitment to stay and that they've seen that it's secure, and that we have a commitment to not allow the Taliban back into the area.
That's Col.
Steve Williams.
He's Deputy Commander of NATO forces in the south, speaking with me here in Kandahar.
Okay, Renee, thanks very much.
Get lots of that hot, Afghan tea, okay?
We'll be hearing from you again on Monday.
October 7th, 2001, five years ago this weekend.
This is NPR News.
The business news starts with the improving finances of an economist.
Twenty-five people working in a variety of fields have been named as 2005 MacArthur Fellows.
They'll each get half a million dollars over the next five years.
One of those so-called genius awards went to Kevin Murphy, an economist at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business.
As NPR's Kathleen Schalch reports, Murphy takes an expansive view of what economics can reveal about the world.
Murphy's work has delved into issues ranging from drug addiction to wage inequality to the value of medical research.
He says in questions of public policy, economics has a lot to bring to the table.
It gives us a perspective that's useful for thinking about why people do what they do and how they're likely to respond if we change those incentives.
Murphy's latest research focuses on the dollar value of increased life expectancy.
What we do is based on how people make choices, whether it's choices about whether to smoke or not or whether to take a dangerous job or not or whether to buy a safer car or a less safe car.
I mean, these are choices that people make every day that affect, you know, their life expectancy, and affect risks that they take of death in any given situation.
And so we try to use that kind of evidence to say, `What does people's behavior tell us about how much they value longevity?'
A lot, it turns out.

On average, people are willing to pay about $500 to reduce their probability of death by one in 10,000, which means that medical research that reduced deaths from cancer by 1 percent would have an economic value to Americans of half a trillion dollars.
Murphy says he will use his fellowship to help fund his next project.
Well, the question we're trying to answer is: What are the key elements of how we get better at producing new ideas or new products or other forms of innovation?
The investigation will take care of all that, right?
He's excited about it.
He got the news about the MacArthur award on his cell phone as he was driving to work.
He called his wife, and then...
Finished my drive into work and started working.
Kathleen Schalch, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
Hillary Clinton has to win the state of Texas or her campaign for president is finished.
That's the latest stark warning for the New York senator coming from both political professionals and media commentators.
They say the Clinton campaign is like Colonel William B.
Travis at the Alamo.
Clinton has to draw a line in the sand and declare that the advancing army of Barack Obama stops in Texas once and for all.
From Dallas, NPR's Wade Goodwyn reports.
Just one month ago, Obama was down more than 20 points to Hillary Clinton in Texas.
She has the endorsement of most of the state's leading Democratic politicians and can count on a sizable Hispanic electorate to vote for her.
But after 10 Obama wins in a row, her 20-point lead has all but vanished.
The latest CNN poll shows Clinton lead inside the four-point margin for error.
And Richard Murray at the University of Houston says that leaves her with no margin for error.
Well, she's absolutely got to do well in the Hispanic parts of the state, from El Paso in the West to San Antonio, down to Brownsville and the valley.
That might be as much as 40 percent of the Democratic vote or as little as 30 percent.
Unify that Hispanic support, try to get those 65 percent level she got in California and try to drive turnout up.
Murray is a professor of political science at the University of Houston, who follows Texas politics closely.

If she cannot get close to her California level percentages, it gets increasingly difficult to carry the state, because African-Americans will probably constitute 25 percent of the primary vote, but they will be much more unified in supporting Senator Obama.
Then, the Hispanic vote will be behind Senator Clinton.
Let's hear the news for the next president of the United States.
(Soundbite of applause)
Last week, while Obama was in Wisconsin, Hillary Clinton was already in El Paso, San Antonio and the Rio Grande Valley, shoring up the backbone of her support.
Well, I can't think of any better place to start our campaign for Texas than right here in El Paso.
The question is, given the momentum Barack Obama is carrying into Texas, how deep is he going to cut into the Hispanic vote?
If he takes 40 percent or more, that will spell trouble for Clinton.
But Gonzalo Barrientos, who served for 31 years in the Texas legislature and is now chairman of the Tejano Democrats of Texas, predicts that's not going to happen.
Some people may talk about the 18- and 20- and 25-year-olds, but in terms of the Tejano, we are loyal, and that passes on to our children.
If it were up to elected officials, Clinton would have Texas locked up.
The Clintons have been campaigning for Democrats in the Lone Star state for more than two decades.
And it's not just whites and Hispanic politicians who are loyal to Hillary Clinton.
John Wiley Price is a Dallas County commissioner and one of the most influential African-American leaders in north Texas.
We've got to understand that you can't just abandon your friend.
And if you can't support your friends, who can you support?
The problem for Clinton is that while the county commissioner is with her, his African-American supporters are giving him an earful for not getting on the Obama train.
And this is one way that Texas is different politically from California.
Black turnout could approach 25 percent of the total, two or three times more than in California.
In this diverse political setting, turnabout is fair play.
John Wiley Price says if Clinton can move up from 8 to 10 percent of the black vote to 15 percent, it could be just enough.
I am available.
I'm not just in the lip service.
I'm available to do whatever she needs me to do to help her secure at least minimum 15 percent of the vote.
In recent statewide primaries, roughly 800,000 Democrats have voted in Texas.
But on March 4th, party officials expect the turnout to be north of 2 million voters.
This makes history a poor guide, because the old voting pool is going to get swamped.
Thirty-nine-year-old Rafael Anchia believes many of the new voters are going to be like him, under 40, fed up with the Bush administration in particular and the political status quo in general.
I think Democratic primary turnout will be on a scale that we have not seen in recent history, modern history.
Fed(ph) and good-looking, articulate and ambitious, Anchia is a Dallas state representative and president of the National Association of Latino-Elected Officials.
State Rep.
ANCHIA: Like him, I'm the son of immigrants.

If Senator Obama's father could be born somewhere else and he went to Columbia undergrad and Harvard Law School and got elected and stands at the precipice of the presidency, what it does for me is affirm that the American dream is still alive and very present.
Maybe it will be the young vote that decides the Texas primary, or maybe the Hispanic vote, or black turnout, or white women in East Texas.
In a contest this close, neither candidate can afford to leave the other supporters alone.
Wade Goodwyn, NPR News, Dallas.
Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney was in the economically depressed state of Michigan today.
Romney told a rally in Southfield that if he's elected, he will not rest until Michigan makes a comeback.
Governor Romney is hoping to edge out Arizona Senator John McCain, who made a comeback himself in the New Hampshire primary.
Like most NBA teams, the Dallas Mavericks are watching the current playoffs.
They have not made the postseason for two years.
But there are bigger problems facing this team that's owned by billionaire and TV personality Mark Cuban.
Earlier this year, Sports Illustrated revealed a corporate workplace rife with sexual harassment and abuse.
Cuban hired a dynamic new CEO to help deal with the scandal.
As NPR's Tom Goldman reports, Cynthia Marshall is determined to make the Mavericks a shining example for the NBA.
And just a warning to listeners, there is graphic language in this story.
On a recent morning in Dallas at the Mavericks headquarters, employees were gathering for a respect in the workplace meeting.
It felt more like a party.
